title.narrative: SHO Emergency relief and rehabilitation support for Nepal

description.narrative: Although Plan has been working in Nepal for the past 38 years, this was not in these specific target areas. Therefore, prior to the earthquake, there were no Plan interventions on which to build.

SUMMARY In April 2015 a massive earthquake struck Nepal, 77 kilometres northwest of Kathmandu. Over 7,500 people died and more than 14,000 were injured. Although Plan was already active in Nepal at the time, this was mostly in areas that were not affected by the earthquake. After carrying out a rapid needs assessment, Plan quickly started working in Sindhupalchowk and Dolakha, two of the 14 most affected districts. In these areas, water systems had been damaged and people didn’t have access to clean and safe drinking water. Children’s lives were changed dramatically, some were separated from their families, others were injured or deeply traumatised. This project is focusing on child protection and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), targeting the children who are affected and their families. Plan Nepal is implementing the project with its local partners. The project started 1 May 2015 and will run till 30 April, 2017.

The earthquake caused many problems in Nepal. -During the earthquake many of the water transportation systems in the rural areas of the country were either partially or completely destroyed. These systems, many of which were more than 25 years old, transported clean drinking water from natural sources in the mountains to the villages, which relied on them. -The earthquake damaged many latrines (toilets). Without them, many villagers were forced to urinate and defecate in the open. In addition to causing diseases, this also exposed these villagers to potential harm, due to snakebites or other hazards, for example. -Many children lost their loved ones during the earthquake, or were severely traumatised in other ways. Schools were also destroyed, meaning children could not continue their education. -Natural disasters like this one often cause an increase in child trafficking. This was also the case in Nepal. -After the earthquake, adolescents did not have enough access to hygiene materials.

The end beneficiaries of the project are children, particularly girls. And thanks to improved water and sanitary provisions, the families of the children and other community members will also benefit.

To supply water to the affected villages, water schemes must be restored. And once they are restored they will provide water for those villages for many years. The restoration of these water schemes is being driven by the communities and local governments, and local administrators are also being included in the process. So while Plan is funding these restoration schemes, they are being carried out with the support of the communities, making them feel like the ‘owners’ of the process. And the same goes for the latrines.
The CFS are temporary structures made from materials that last for just a few seasons. They were set up for six months to provide the necessary services directly after the earthquake. After six months they were transformed into Temporary Learning Centers (TLC). These are now being used for various purposes, such as hosting Children Village Development Meetings.
Plan is working with local organisations, which are implementing the projects. An important part of working with these organisations is building up their capacity. Many of them do not yet have the capability of implementing programmes in accordance with international standards, so Plan is building up their capacity to do so. When Plan leaves, these local organisations will be able to take over the projects.
